Award.AwardTitle: San Francisco State Noyce Scholarship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The San Francisco State University (SFSU) Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program will increase the quality, quantity and diversity of well-prepared science and mathematics teachers in California public schools serving the State's neediest students. The project will support 28 unique scholarship recipients with 10, 3, 5, 5, and 5 new recipients in project years 1 through 5 respectively. The project builds on SFSU's successful track record of supporting future teachers entering middle school and high school and sustaining a vibrant pre-service teacher community. It leverages multiple resources to create an intensive experience based on recommendations from the research literature on the importance of professional community and the development of educational leadership. Noyce Fellows meet in regularly scheduled leadership seminars and play key roles in important national initiatives such as the Algebra Project and the Strategic Education Research Project. SFSU is recognized as one of the nation's most ethnically, culturally, and economically diverse institutions, and graduates the majority of teachers in the San Francisco Unified School District. Pre-service STEM teachers trained through the Noyce Program have a positive impact on many high-needs schools in the immediate area. The commitment of the California State University Chancellor's Office to spread the SFSU teacher development model means that insights and innovations from the Noyce Program will also be rapidly deployed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The San Francisco State University Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program was funded by the National Science Foundation in September 2011 to conduct a five-year program designed to recruit, encourage, and support undergraduate majors and credential candidates in Science and Mathematics who wished to become secondary teachers in high-needs schools. This funding was extended to include a sixth year for this program. 

For each year of the program, a cohort of SFSU Noyce Scholars attend twice-monthly Noyce seminars; serve in special internships focused on inquiry into the teaching and learning of math and science; develop and implement inquiry based lessons as professional development for peers; and engage in action research. All SFSU Noyce Scholars are focused on and committed to teaching in high-needs schools and empowering students who have been most often under-served by our educational system. The SFSU Noyce program aimed to offer up to ten Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarships of $10,000 each, annually, over a period of 5 years. The program has funded a total of 49 individual scholars. Of the scholars who completed the credential program (n=47) program, 93% of our alumni have been offered teaching positions and are currently teaching STEM in high needs schools.

 The SFSU Noyce experience included the following:

  • Planning meetings for program activities and evaluation activities.
  • An initial all day orientation event held at a STEM Education Partner institution in the SF Bay Area (California Academy of Sciences and the Exploratorium for example).
  • Twelve Noyce Fellow Seminars, conducted on Fridays from September to May. Seminars each had a specific topic/focus and some included special presentations by a variety of experts.
  • Four special informative programs held on Friday afternoons. These programs included Science and Math Workshops presented by the Center for Science and Math Education (CSME) Noyce Teachers-in- Residence (TiRs), an Experienced Teacher Panel; an Action-Research poster presentation/CSME Banquet, and the Noyce End-of-Year Barbeque.
  • Internship placements in schools designated as “high needs.”
  • Five Noyce CSME Noyce Teachers-in Residence who served as mentors and facilitators for our Noyce cohort. The TiRs worked in a variety of ways with all the scholars across the course of the SFSU Noyce program. For the Noyce Scholars specifically, they provided significant support activities. These activities included working collaboratively to develop spring Math and Science Workshops conducted by the credential scholars for SFSU undergraduate STEM teaching Fellows and, when and where feasible, providing individualized support both on campus and at student teaching/internship placements
  • Action Research projects by all Noyce Scholars.
  • Culminating Experience Presentation of the research work completed by all the Noyce Fellows completed across each academic year. 
  • Opportunities for scholars to attend conferences and Noyce sponsored and focused professional development.  

Data show that this has been a very productive program across all 6 years for our Scholars. There is evidence of their growth and development as educators as a large majority stays passionately committed to teaching in high needs schools. Although unique as individuals with very different backgrounds, yearly program evaluations give clear evidence that each SFSU Noyce Scholar cares deeply about Science and/or Math, their students, and considers themselves an active member of a greater community of teachers and mentors. A majority of our Scholars remain in touch with each other and provide support and peer mentoring as they move into teaching or enter the SFSU credential program There is also evidence of continued interest in bringing research into their classroom practice and a desire to serve in leadership roles.

Findings from all evaluation activities and collected data, along with observations made during Noyce events, provide strong evidence that the SFSU Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program created a true Fellowship, learning community, and support base for and among the Scholars. In the words of one of our year six cohort members:

 “…I honestly do not think I would be pursuing a career in science education if it weren’t for NOYCE. I truly am grateful for this program because it has allowed me to meet wonderful peers who all want to be teachers and educators. But it has also allowed me to meet wonderful mentors and faculty that have truly been inspiring and a joy to work with. I hope that NOYCE can continue because it has changed my life.” (Noyce Fellow, Spring Questionnaire 2017)
